bibl.title: Letter from J. F. Siler to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 20, 1942

div1.p: Siler has read Saleeby's report on the 1899 fever epidemic at Columbia Barracks and is sure that it was dengue fever.

div1.head: Letter from J. F. Siler to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 20, 1942
div1.opener:
THE PRESIDENT
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
May 20, 1942.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
This will acknowledge your note of May 16th enclosing a photostatic
copy of the report of Dr. Najieb M. Saleeby on an epidemic occurring at
Columbia Barracks, Quemados, Cuba in 1899.

I have read this report with a great deal of interest and have no hesi-
tation whatsoever in stating that Dr. Saleeby was undoubtedly dealing with
an epidemic of dengue fever. The principal diagnostic points, from the
viewpoint of considering the epidemic as being one of dengue fever, were the
intense muscular pains, the very severe post-orbital headaches, the saddle-
back types of temperature noted and the rash.

It is a most interesting description of an epidemic of dengue. Should
you care to look into the matter further, I will be very glad to bring around
to you the monograph of our work on the mechanics of the transmission of
dengue fever which, as you know, was carried out in the Philippines. The
monograph covers the historical side as well as the diagnostic phases.

Thank you very much for permitting me to read this most interesting
report.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, J.F. Siler J. F. Siler.
3434 - 34th Place, N.W.
(President Gorgas Memorial
Institute - K)
General J. R. Kean
2804 N St., N.W.
Washington, D.C.
